node.title: Hereâ€™s what to watch for in the October jobs report.
node.alt: More-robust hiring at restaurants, bars and other leisure and hospitality businesses may serve as a tailwind.
node.description: Economists are looking for a gain of 450,000 positions, with a tailwind from hiring by leisure and hospitality businesses.
node.content: ["The economy\u2019s underlying strength \u2014 and its ability to shake off the lingering effects of the Delta variant of the coronavirus \u2014 will come into focus Friday morning when the government reports on hiring and employment in October.", "Economists polled by Bloomberg are looking for a gain of 450,000 jobs, a big improvement from the 194,000 added in September, the year\u2019s weakest showing. More-robust hiring at restaurants, bars and other leisure and hospitality businesses may serve as a tailwind, along with continued robust activity in white-collar sectors like professional and business services.", "\u201cI do expect to see a figure that\u2019s much better than we saw in September,\u201d said Greg Daco, chief U.S. economist at Oxford Economics. \u201cThe health situation has improved quite a bit.\u201d", "The Commerce Department reported last week that the economy grew by 0.5 percent in the third quarter, compared with 1.6 percent in the second quarter. Economists attributed the slowdown to the resurgent pandemic and supply chain holdups that have caused shortages of key components and have hampered manufacturers.", "After the economy added more than one million jobs in July, employment growth has slowed sharply. Even though there are five million fewer jobs than there were before the pandemic, some employers are complaining of a shortage of workers, as many people remain on the sidelines of the job market. The labor force \u2014 the working-age population employed or looking for a job \u2014 actually contracted by 183,000 in September.", "In theory, the demand for workers should be drawing more people into the labor force, but the participation rate is nearly two percentage points below where it was before the pandemic. Early retirements have been a factor.", "A federal supplement to unemployment benefits expired in early September, and experts are watching whether the end of that assistance \u2014 and a depletion of savings accumulated from other emergency programs \u2014 increases the availability of workers.", "So far, those effects have been muted, as health concerns and child care challenges have continued to affect many families. At the same time, the labor shortage has given workers a measure of leverage they\u2019ve not experienced in recent years, contributing to wage growth.", "\u201cFor the last 25, maybe 30 years, labor has been on its back heels and losing its share of the economic pie,\u201d said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody\u2019s Analytics. \u201cBut that dynamic is now shifting.\u201d", "For many companies, the increase in labor costs is a challenge in an uncertain business environment. And lingering supply-chain troubles have meant that shipping costs \u2014 which are passed onto consumers in the form of pricier goods \u2014 remain significantly above prepandemic levels.", "Still, there are reasons to be optimistic. The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it would begin winding down the large-scale bond purchases that have been underway since the pandemic struck, signaling that it considers the economy healthy enough to be weaned from the extra stimulus."]
